name: Grafarkirkja - Iceland's Oldest Turf Church
description: Grafarkirkja holds distinction as Iceland's oldest turf church with parts dating back to 17th century and historical mentions from as early as 1240, making it tangible connection to medieval Iceland when Sturlunga Saga chronicled violent power struggles among chieftain families during final decades before Norwegian annexation ended Commonwealth period. The first documented mention appears in Sturlunga Saga circa 1240, referencing church at this site that served Höfðaströnd coastal community in North Iceland's Skagafjörður region, positioning Grafarkirkja among Iceland's earliest documented church sites with continuous history spanning nearly 800 years of worship, community gathering, and spiritual significance. The current structure incorporates 17th-century wooden elements making it Iceland's oldest wooden church, demonstrating remarkable preservation despite Iceland's harsh climate, limited maintenance resources, and historical periods when church fell into disuse and neglect—this survival represents both construction quality and eventual recognition of irreplaceable historical value. Located about 4 kilometers south of Hofsós village just off road 76 in Höfðaströnd coastal area, the church occupies dramatic setting where farmland meets coastline with views across Skagafjörður bay to distant mountains, creating isolated beauty that characterizes much of Iceland's rural ecclesiastical architecture positioned to serve scattered farming communities rather than concentrated towns.
address: Höfðaströnd, 565 Hofsós, Skagafjörður, Iceland (4 km south of Hofsós, off road 76)
